text:
1.6 allowed for svg files without <!DOCTYPE svg PUBLIC ...>, but 1.7beta1 does
not. As other programs do allow for such files, batik 1.7 should not make an
exception.

A quote from http://wiki.svg.org/Doctype says:

Some people recommend that you do not use a DOCTYPE declaration in your SVG
files since they consider them to cause more problems than they solve.

So this implies optional use of the DOCTYPE declaration.

Error message:
Root element namespace does not match that requested:
Requested: http://www.w3.org/2000/svg
Found: null
creator: mack@ifis.cs.tu-bs.de
cam@apache.org
text:
It's not the DOCTYPE declaration that is required, but a namespace declaration
so that your elements are actually in the SVG namespace.  The behaviour was
changed to require a namespace declaration, and one way to declare it is to use
the DOCTYPE.  So if you don't want to use a DOCTYPE decaration (which is fine),
you'll need to declare the namespace explicitly:

  <svg xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'>
  ...

creator: mack@ifis.cs.tu-bs.de
text:
batik-1.7 is the only SVG-Viewer we found here (batik 1.6, inkscape, konqueror, 
MS-Internet Explorer), to enforce the need for the namespace declaration. So 
batik could make the 1.6 behaviour configurable, as long it is widely accepted 
elsewhere.

I do understand the wish to conform to standards only, on the other hand.
